instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.5V_S4: What is 5V_S4? This is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S4” – when you see this, assume the person typing it meant to type “PP5V_S4”.
definitions.3V3_S4: What is 3V3_S4? This is an abbreviation of PP3V3_S4, a 3.3v power rail when the machine is in an S4 state. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has 20V but current is cycling
threads.message: This came in as a no-spill but it looks like it was exposed to some type of very minimal moisture. Very subtle but I had to replace <RESISTOR>R3509</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R3539</RESISTOR>. Cleaned it in the ultrasonic. No change. I can't find any shorts. Every 5 or 6 seconds it will try to turn on and a small amount of current will go through for a split second. Stays at 20V the whole time. PPBUS is at 12.6V but moves between 12.59 and 12.61V which makes me think something is pulling it down slightly. Not sure where to go next.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has 20V but current is cycling
threads.message:
Check which secondary voltages pulse; all S4/3/0 states.
Also check all rails in page 78, Power FETs.

Try to start in SMC bypass too.

<RESISTOR>R3509</RESISTOR>/39 open could cause an issue on <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> power rail.
Compare diode mode to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and L3500.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has 20V but current is cycling
threads.message: Had a short on <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL>, just had to hunting for it. Finally found it on <CAPACITOR>C4202</CAPACITOR>. Good to go now. Thanks for the help.
